purpose: To conduct a scoping review to identify articles discussing research waste in health and biomedical sciences, distinguishing them from other types of waste (e.g., medical waste, food waste, industrial waste).

fields.name: Waste Type Discussed
fields.description: What kind of waste is discussed in this article?
fields.guidance_notes: Read the title and abstract carefully. Identify and describe the type of waste being discussed. Look for key terms and context clues that indicate the nature of the waste.

fields.name: Waste Origin
fields.description: Where does this kind of waste typically come from?
fields.guidance_notes:
Based on your general knowledge and the article context, identify where this kind of waste primarily originates in the real world:
- Research settings (clinical trials, laboratories, systematic reviews, grant processes, publications)
- Healthcare delivery (hospitals, clinics, surgical suites)
- Industrial/commercial settings (factories, food production)
- Agricultural settings (farms, crop production)
- Biological/physiological processes

fields.name: Research Process Waste Discussion
fields.description: Does this article discuss waste in the research process itself?
fields.guidance_notes: Reflect on whether the article addresses inefficiencies or problems in how research is conducted, reported, or used. Aspects of Research Waste (MINUS framework, Rosengaard et al, 2024; expanded): Methodological, Invisible, Negligible, Underreported, Structural, Emerging, Summative. Ask yourself: Is this about improving research quality and efficiency or about managing physical materials and operations?

fields.name: Waste Category
fields.description: What waste category best describes this article?
fields.guidance_notes: Select the single best category that describes the waste discussed in the article. Refer to the definitions for guidance on each category.
fields.conditional_logic: Selection of 'Asserted_research_waste', 'Quoted_research_waste', or 'Not_sure_see_previous_step' will result in INCLUSION for Level 2 screening. Selection of any other category will result in EXCLUSION.

review_objective: The goal is to conduct a scoping review to identify articles discussing research waste in health and biomedical sciences, distinguishing them from other types of waste (e.g., medical waste, food waste, industrial waste).
review_questions: What constitutes research waste in health and biomedical sciences, and how can it be distinguished from other forms of waste in the literature?
global_instructions: If you select Asserted_research_waste or Quoted_research_waste, the study will be INCLUDED for Level 2 screening.
If you select any other waste category, the study will be EXCLUDED.
If you select Not_sure_see_previous_step, the study will be INCLUDED for Level 2 screening.
The screening system includes a simulated peer 'pree' review process that helps validate categorization decisions, but this does not require manual input from screeners.

items.value: Authors explicitly say it's about research waste (terms like 'research waste,' 'avoidable waste in research,' 'reducing waste in research').
Article covers research waste concepts (redundant trials, poor methods, publication bias, selective reporting) but does not use the phrase 'research waste.'
Article is about food waste in any setting.
Article is about dangerous materials (chemicals, toxins, radioactive substances) needing special disposal.
Article is about plastic waste or pollution.
Article is about waste collection, disposal, or management systems.
Article is about waste from manufacturing or industrial processes.
Article is about contaminated water or water treatment.
Article is about physical clinical waste (sharps, contaminated materials, surgical waste), not research waste.
Article is about inefficient clinician time use in healthcare delivery.
Article is about over-ordering or unnecessary supply procurement in clinical/operational settings.
Article is about unnecessary animal use in research or animal welfare issues.
Article is about unused, expired, or improperly disposed medications.
Article is about medical muscle loss (cachexia, sarcopenia, atrophy).
Article is about biological byproducts of metabolism (urea, CO2, etc.).
Article is about agricultural waste from plants.
Category unclear; rely on reflection from Question 3.
